Overview.Summary: The 2020 Romanian legislative election saw the Social Democratic Party (PSD) emerge as the largest political party (1). However, the PNL, led by Ludovic Orban, claimed victory and declared themselves the "moral winners" (2, 5). The final results, declared by Jean Mensa, showed that even if the second candidate's votes were added to the first, it would not change the outcome (3). This election was seen as pivotal for the country's future in the European mainstream (5). The US also held their Senate and House elections, with full results available (6). The 2020 presidential election in the US saw Joe Biden win the presidency (7). Meanwhile, Venezuela's legislative election resulted in a political standoff (8). The day after the Romanian elections, PM Orban resigned and Nicolae Ciucă was appointed as interim PM (9). The Seychelles saw their first opposition victory in 44 years (10). Overall, this election was significant in shaping the future of Romania's government and its relationship with the European Union.

Overview.Summary: The 2020 Romanian legislative election was held on December 6, 2020 (6, 7, 8), with the final results announced on December 9, 2020 (1). The election was originally scheduled for 2024 but was moved up to April 2022, with local elections also taking place (2). The opposition Social Democrats took a narrow lead over the ruling National Liberal Party (6), while Prime Minister Ludovic Orban was expected to remain in power (7, 8). The election had significant polling errors, similar to the 2016 election in the United States (5, 9). The electoral college later confirmed Joe Biden's victory in the US election (10).

Timeline.Text: Romania's parliamentary election takes place, with the opposition Social Democrats (PSD) taking a narrow lead over the governing National Liberal Party.
The first exit polls from the Romanian parliamentary election are published, showing a tight race between the PSD and the Liberal Party.
Hans von Spakovsky, an expert on civil rights and civil justice, discusses ways to prevent similar issues from occurring in future US elections.
The final results of the Romanian parliamentary election are announced, with the PSD maintaining their lead but the Liberal Party's percentage of the vote changing slightly.
The US electoral college affirms Joe Biden's presidential election victory, one of the final steps in the process of determining the next US President.

Overview.Summary: The 2020 Romanian legislative election was held on December 6, 2020 (1,3,4). The ruling party, the National Liberal Party (PNL), suffered its worst election result since 1996 (2). Despite this, the current Prime Minister Ludovic Orban claimed victory (4,9). The opposition Social Democrats (PSD) took a narrow lead over the PNL (7), but the final results showed that the PSD received the most votes (8). The election was seen as pivotal for Romania's future in the European mainstream (4,10). Blockchain technology was implemented in the election (5,6).

Timeline.Text: Romania holds parliamentary elections, with the government deciding to postpone the original date of 6 December to March 2021 due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Blockchain technology is used for the first time in Romanian elections.
The implementation plan for Romania's 2020-2024 National Defence Strategy and Defence White Paper is approved by the CSAT.
The final results of the parliamentary elections are announced, with the Social Democrat Party (PSD) receiving the most votes.

The left-wing Social Democrat Party (PSD) wins the most votes in the parliamentary elections, but the center-right National Liberal Party (PNL) and pro-EU Union for Romania's Salvation (USR-PLUS) also secure significant victories.

Overview.Summary: Romania held parliamentary elections on December 6, 2020, and Ludovic Orban, the current prime minister, announced his resignation the day after (1,2). Orban, who has been in power since November 2019, distanced himself from Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban (3,4). Orban has emphasized the importance of finalizing the BRUA gas pipeline project to diversify gas sources for Europe (5). He has also stated that the outcome of the upcoming elections will be decisive for the country's future (6). Orban has ruled out a post-election lockdown due to the economic impact (7). Social democrats have criticized the government for not publishing the budget proposal for 2021 (8). In the end, Orban's party was reelected, but with a lower majority (9,10).

Timeline.Text: Romanian Prime Minister Ludovic Orban distances himself from Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban over EU veto on Hungary and Poland.
PM Ludovic Orban vows that there will be no post-election lockdown in Romania.
Romania holds parliamentary elections, with Orban's center-right party projected to win.
PM Ludovic Orban votes in the parliamentary elections and expresses hope for the country's future.
PM Ludovic Orban announces his resignation from office following the parliamentary elections.

Overview.Summary: Romanian Minister of Defense, Nicolae Ciucă, has become the interim prime minister after the resignation of Ludovic Orban (1,6,10). Ciucă is a member of the National Liberal Party (PNL) and is running for a Senate seat in the 2020 Romanian legislative election (1,2). He has been described as a "căpitan" (captain) in the military (3,4,5,9) and has received the "Legiunea de Merit" (Legion of Merit) from the US Ambassador Adrian Zuckerman (8). Ciucă has stated that the pandemic will not stop during the holiday season (9) and has been involved in the preparation for the vaccination campaign (9).

Timeline.Text: Romanian Prime Minister Ludovic Orban resigns following poor results of his party in the parliamentary elections.
President Klaus Iohannis appoints Nicolae Ciucă, the current Minister of Defense, as interim Prime Minister.
Nicolae Ciucă gives a short statement, announcing that he will continue to handle the COVID-19 pandemic and the country's economic measures.
US Ambassador Adrian Zuckerman presents Nicolae Ciucă with the 'Legion of Merit' award.
Colonel Mircea Dogaru addresses General Nicolae Ciucă in a public statement regarding the events of December 1989.
Colonel Mircea Dogaru continues his public statement, addressing General Nicolae Ciucă once again.
Nicolae Ciucă chairs a meeting of the National Committee for Coordinating Activities on Vaccination Against COVID-19.
Nicolae Ciucă is photographed casting his vote in the parliamentary elections.
Nicolae Ciucă gives a brief statement, confirming that the London Bridge and Borough Market incidents are being treated as terrorist attacks.
Nicolae Ciucă gives another short statement, thanking outgoing Prime Minister Ludovic Orban.

Overview.Summary: The 2020 Romanian legislative election took place on December 6, 2020 (1, 6, 14, 16, 19, 20). It was initially scheduled to be held in March 2021 but was postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic (1). The ruling National Liberal Party (PNL) lost the election to the opposition Social Democratic Party (PSD) (2, 8, 18). The election also saw the emergence of a far-right nationalist party that received a record number of votes (20). President Klaus Iohannis accepted the resignation of former Prime Minister Ludovic Orban and named Nicolae Ciuca as interim Prime Minister (2, 3). The new Prime Minister Florin Citu was sworn in on December 23, 2020 (4). The final results showed PSD as the largest political party in the parliament, followed by PNL, USR PLUS, AUR, and UDMR (5, 7, 12, 17). The turnout for the election was 33.24% of the total number of voters (7). The next parliamentary election is scheduled for 2024 (9, 11). The election campaign started on November 6, 2020 and ended on December 5, 2020 (13). Blockchain technology was used for the first time in Romanian elections (19).
